instruction: I want to report a fraud but I'm worried about creating an account online. Can I report anonymously?
output: You can absolutely report fraud without creating an account if that makes you feel more comfortable. When using Action Fraud's online reporting tool, you have three options: register for an account, log into an existing account, or continue as a guest. If you choose to continue as a guest, you can still make your report but you'll only receive updates by email or post rather than being able to track progress online. While registering does give you extra features like saving partially completed reports and tracking progress through your dashboard, the most important thing is that you report the fraud in whatever way feels right for you. You can also report by phone on 0300 123 2040 (Monday to Friday, 8am-8pm) if you prefer speaking to someone directly. Remember, their web chat is available 24 hours a day if you need help while reporting online. Your safety and comfort matter most - choose whichever reporting method feels best for you.
source_document: How to report fraud and cyber crime

instruction: I started reporting a fraud online but got interrupted. Will I lose all the information I entered?
output: If you registered for an account when you started your report, you're in luck - you can save and resume partially completed reports. Simply log back into your account, go to 'My account' and then 'My reports', and you should be able to continue where you left off. This is one of the helpful features designed to make reporting easier, especially for complex cases that might take time to document properly. If you didn't register and were reporting as a guest, unfortunately the information may not have been saved. However, don't let this discourage you from reporting - it's still worth completing a new report as it helps protect both you and others. The web chat feature is available 24 hours a day if you need help while filling out your report. Next time, consider registering at the start if you think you might need to take breaks while reporting. Your report is valuable regardless of how many attempts it takes to complete it.
source_document: How to report fraud and cyber crime

instruction: My business is being cyber attacked right now. Is there emergency help available?
output: Yes, there is emergency help available for live cyber attacks. Call Action Fraud immediately on 0300 123 2040 - this emergency service for businesses, charities, and organisations is available 24 hours a day, 7 days a week when you're suffering an active cyber attack. Don't wait - call now while the attack is in progress. The advisors can provide immediate guidance to help you respond to the ongoing attack. Remember, if you suffer a data breach, you may also need to report it to the Information Commissioner's Office (ICO) within 72 hours under GDPR rules - you can do this at ico.org.uk. Action Fraud won't automatically pass your data breach report to the ICO, so you'll need to report to both organizations separately. The immediate priority is getting help to stop the attack, so call the emergency number right away. Keep records of what's happening as this will be important for both your cyber attack report and any potential data breach reporting requirements.
source_document: How to report fraud and cyber crime

instruction: I'm worried about what happens to my personal information when I report a fraud. Will it be kept secure?
output: Your concerns about data security are completely understandable, and Action Fraud takes protecting your information very seriously. When you make a report, they promise to only collect the information they need for the investigation, and they will protect it to ensure nobody who shouldn't have access can see it. Your personal information will only be shared with police or anti-fraud agencies who need it to investigate the crime and protect others. They will never make your personal information available for commercial use without your permission, and they won't keep it longer than necessary. If they do need to share your information with other organisations to give you better public services, they will let you know and, where possible, give you the option to say no. The data you provide is totally secure and follows all legal requirements including the Data Protection Act 2018. You have rights to know what information they hold about you and to ask for corrections if needed. Your privacy and data security are protected by law, and reporting fraud shouldn't add to your worries about personal information being misused.

instruction: I'm reporting a fraud on behalf of my elderly parent who has dementia. Will Action Fraud provide extra support?
output: Yes, Action Fraud provides enhanced services for vulnerable victims, which includes people suffering from mental disorders. When contacting Action Fraud on behalf of your parent, please make it clear that you're reporting on behalf of a vulnerable victim - this will trigger their enhanced service protocols. The Victims' Code recognizes that vulnerable victims need additional support, and Action Fraud is committed to providing the best possible service in these circumstances. They understand that elderly people with conditions like dementia can be particularly targeted by fraudsters and need special consideration. Everyone who reports fraud to Action Fraud has the option to receive ongoing support from Victim Support, a charity that provides free, confidential help. This partnership is central to their commitment to putting victims at the heart of the process. Your parent is fortunate to have you advocating for them. Don't hesitate to ask for the enhanced service - it's specifically designed for situations like this where someone needs extra care and attention during the reporting process.
source_document: Vulnerable victims and the Victims' Code

instruction: My teenage daughter was targeted by an online scam. Does she qualify for special victim support?
output: Yes, your daughter absolutely qualifies for enhanced victim support. Under the Victims' Code, anyone under the age of 17 at the time of the offence is automatically classified as a vulnerable victim and entitled to an enhanced service. This recognition acknowledges that young people may need additional support when dealing with crime, especially online scams which can be particularly confusing and distressing for teenagers. When you contact Action Fraud, make sure to mention that you're reporting on behalf of a vulnerable victim under 17 - this will ensure she receives the appropriate level of support. Action Fraud works in partnership with Victim Support, which offers free, confidential assistance specifically designed to help young victims cope with the impact of crime. There are also specialized resources available for young people, including Childnet International and the UK Safer Internet Centre, which provide education and support about online safety. Your daughter's age actually works in her favor here - she's entitled to extra protection and support that recognizes young people need different care when they're victims of crime.
source_document: Vulnerable victims and the Victims' Code
